GateDocument.TextWithNodes:
The Financial Services Authority is seeking independent legal advice on whether Equitable Life members who did not have guaranteed annuity policies were victims of mis-selling.
This move by the City watchdog could affect other pension companies that are reeling from the cost to the industry of honouring guaranteed annuity liabilities, estimated at up to £10bn ($14bn).
The FSA announced in February it was examining whether Equitable policyholders who bought policies last year could claim they had been mis-sold - particularly those who bought policies after the Law Lords ruled in July against the mutual's stance on guaranteed annuities.
Depending on its legal advice, the FSA's could affect other pension groups. If the regulator decides these policyholders were misled and suffered a loss, they could be eligible for compensation.
More than 50 life assurers had some exposure to guaranteed annuity-type products. However, most have dealt with the problem by drawing on their "orphan assets" of surplus capital in their with-profits funds, or by receiving capital injections from shareholders.
Analysts said it would not be easy for other policyholders to prove they had suffered a loss as a result of the existence of the guaranteed annuity policies - a must if they are to claim compensation.
Equitable has asked Nicholas Warren QC to advise whether customers sold pension policies without annuity guarantees should have been told about the troubled mutual's exposure to guaranteed annuity liabilities - now put at £2.6bn.
Vanni Treves, Equitable's chairman, has acknowledged that any liability arising from mis-selling could be "a substantial amount", though he said it would not be of the same scale as the guaranteed annuity liability.
He said quantification of any mis-selling claims would have to be from part of the forthcoming compromise deal between the 90,000 Equitable policyholders with guaranteed annuity policies and the majority who do not have guarantees.
Of Mr Warren's report, Mr Treves said: "I think it will be a very, very important piece of work for the industry as a whole, which is one reason why the FSA is taking its own independent advice upon it".
